transcripts.text: Food is allowed during Virginia's stay at home order, but now one local group hoping to equip the community with tools to grow at least some of their own food at home.  Jasmine Turner learning more about that effort.  She joins us now with more on these resiliency gardens.  Jasmine.

Well, Kurt, if you want to get one of these gardens first, you'll have to fill out an application.  Then beautiful RVA and organization will deliver a six by four raised bed to you.  Once you have it in your yard, you'll be able to utilize online resources that will guide you through growing your own food.
Every season we're going something every season.
Whenever seeds are planted, it creates the opportunity for something to bloom.
It's like a new beginning.  So just knowing that after all of this is over that you can start over, you can grow something to have a little bit of hope.
Nikaya Ellis is prepping the beds of a community garden.
You can do this yourself.  Maybe you won't need to go to the grocery store.
Piece by piece, Duran Chavis is building a symbol of resiliency.

Our work has been to figure out how we can get raised bed boxes directly to individuals in their homes to reduce the need for them to be out and about, going to the grocery store, trying to figure out how to get to the food pantry or what have you.
We're literally growing community through food access.
The organization, Beautiful RVA, will be delivering these six by four raised beds and soil for free to the community.
Mustard greens, kale, cabbages, those will grow really fast.
So food can be grown in what they call resiliency gardens.

Really trying to help people determine on their own terms where their food comes from.  And then also helping with the mental health that's necessary during this time.  You know, really helping people feel hopeful and optimistic.
And what blooms will be more than just nourishment.
Nothing says hope like planting a seed.

Again, you can go online to get all the information you need to apply for one of these resiliency gardens.  And beautiful RVA is also raising money because they want to provide folks with seeds and seedlings as they try to grow their own food.  They're also looking for volunteers to deliver those resiliency gardens.  If you're interested, you'll be able to find all the information you need on NBC12.com.  On your side, Jasmine Turner, NBC12.
